content: I'll be straight with you - things are tight. I make good money at the mill, $85K with overtime. But between the mortgage, the car payments, and everything costing more, it doesn't feel like I'm getting ahead. It feels like I'm running to stay in place.
participant_profile: M, 54, USW member, worked at Clairton coke works for 28 years, McKeesport, third-generation steelworker
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.

content: I'm a single mom. I work full time in a hospital cafeteria. I make $17 an hour. After rent and food and getting my kids to school, there's nothing left. My union fought for that $17 - it used to be $12. But $17 still isn't enough.
participant_profile: F, 46, Hospital cafeteria worker, SEIU member, Wilkinsburg, single mom of two
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.

content: I drive for UPS. Good job, good benefits thanks to the Teamsters. But my wife doesn't have union benefits at her job and her healthcare costs are insane. Every year the premiums go up.
participant_profile: M, 41, UPS driver, Teamsters, North Versailles, family man, politically disengaged until recently
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.

content: I managed a grocery store through the whole pandemic. We were "essential workers" but nobody treated us essential. We got sick, we kept working, and now they're cutting hours because profits are down. Where's the loyalty?
participant_profile: F, 44, Grocery store manager, UFCW, Irwin, worked through entire pandemic
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.

content: Construction is actually doing okay right now. Infrastructure money is flowing. But the cost of living... man. I want to buy a house in McKees Rocks where I grew up, and I can't afford it. Houses that were $80K five years ago are $200K now.
participant_profile: M, 35, Construction worker, Laborers union, McKees Rocks, first-generation college, changed careers
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.

content: I'm retired, fixed income. The pension is good - thank God for the union - but inflation is eating away at it. I'm worried about Social Security. Every election Republicans talk about cutting it.
participant_profile: M, 61, Retired Allegheny County employee, AFSCME, Homestead, pension very important
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.

content: Everything. Gas was the killer this summer. I've got a truck - needed for the job - and it was costing me $100 to fill it. Groceries are insane. My wife says the same cart that used to be $150 is now $250.
participant_profile: M, 54, USW member, worked at Clairton coke works for 28 years, McKeesport, third-generation steelworker
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley
preceding_moderator_q: What's driving these cost increases you're feeling?

content: Healthcare costs. I work at UPMC - the biggest healthcare system in the region - and my own insurance is barely affordable. The deductible is $4,000. I'm a nurse making decent money and I put off going to the doctor because of the cost.
participant_profile: F, 52, Nurse, UPMC (non-union), Penn Hills, frustrated with healthcare employer
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley
preceding_moderator_q: What's driving these cost increases you're feeling?

content: Teachers in Pennsylvania are actually paid okay compared to other states. But my husband was laid off during COVID and only found part-time work. We're a union household but we're still struggling.
participant_profile: F, 38, Elementary school teacher, AFT member, Munhall, grew up in steel family
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley

participant_profile: M, 48, Bus driver, ATU, Pittsburgh city, lifelong Democrat but "not enthusiastic lately"
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley

section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley

participant_profile: M, 57, Electrician, IBEW, Braddock, union hall very active, political junkie

content: I saw a video where he talked about his dad's hands being permanently stained from the work. That's real. That's what my grandfather looked like.
participant_profile: M, 35, Construction worker, Laborers union, McKees Rocks, first-generation college, changed careers
preceding_moderator_q: Let's talk about Tony Marchetti, the Democratic Senate candidate. What do you know about him?

content: My father had hands like that too. He worked at J&L Steel for 38 years. Started right out of high school in '61. Back then you could walk out of South High and into the mill the same day. Good money, good benefits. He bought a house in Hazelwood, raised four kids. When the mills closed in the '80s it destroyed him. Took early retirement, but really he was just— I mean, the whole neighborhood emptied out. People lost their houses, their—
participant_profile: F, 52, Nurse, UPMC (non-union), Penn Hills, frustrated with healthcare employer
